Class GameCommunicator

java.lang.Object

                      nl.uu.cs.ias.pursuerevader.ui.BaseGUI
                          nl.uu.cs.ias.pursuerevader.game.GameCommunicator
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, GameInterface
public abstract class GameCommunicator
extends BaseGUI
implements GameInterface

GameCommunicator class

This class allows communication with the game, and makes sure an applet is started.
It defines the skeleton for a AI and can be extended by implementing the required methods.

Author:
M.v.Zee
See Also:
nl.uu.cs.ias.pursuerevader.game.GameInterface nl.uu.cs.ias.pursuerevader.game.Game, Serialized Form

gameStarted

public abstract void gameStarted()
Called by the game when a game has started..

Specified by:
gameStarted in interface GameInterface

roundStarted

public abstract void roundStarted()
Called by the game when a round has started. A game can consists of any number of rounds, which is determined by the user when starting the simulation.

Specified by:
roundStarted in interface GameInterface

roundEnded

public abstract void roundEnded(boolean evaderWon)
Called by the game when the current round has ended. This happens when the evader has been caught, or when the time is finished. If the evader has not been caught when the time is finished, the evader has won. If the evader has been won, logically, the pursuer wins.

Specified by:
roundEnded in interface GameInterface
Parameters:
evaderWon - Whether the evader was the winner of this round

public void gameEnded()

agentsPlaced

public final void agentsPlaced(Agent pursuer,
                               Agent evader)
Internal method. Called when all agents have been placed into the game. This methods attached agent listeners for both agents.

Parameters:
pursuer - Pursuer agent
evader - Evader agent

startSimulation

protected void startSimulation(int numRounds,
                               boolean paint)
A game is started using this method

When implementing the SOM, it will be necessary to train it by playing this game very often. Similar to the TOTO implementation that you programmed using Netlogo, you do not want to have visual feedback when testing. This can be done by setting the second argument of the startSimulation call to false. When it is set to true, visual feedback will be given.

Specified by:
startSimulation in class BaseGUI
Parameters:
numRounds - The number of rounds to play
paint - Whether to output the game in the Applet, or to play in the background. Usually the game is played in the background when it is played for a large amount of times (when training a neural network for example).

playDefaultAI

protected void playDefaultAI()
Play the default AI for the evader, which simply moves forward all the time.

Specified by:
playDefaultAI in class BaseGUI

setRelativity

protected void setRelativity(int relativity)
There are three different way in which the game can be visualized using the Applet:
- GridProperties.ABSOLUTE: Use absolute axes, the agents will both move and turn
- GridProperties.POSITION_RELATIVE: Set (0,0) on the position of the pursuer
- GridProperties.RELATIVE: Position relative, and also rotate axes so that the angle of the pursuer is always 0.

The first choice is the most clear one, because it will show the movement and direction of both agents. It is advised that you use the RELATIVE mode when training the SOM. This will decrease the numbers of parameters that matter drastically. The direction and movement of the pursuer are both set to zero when playing in this mode, so the only values that matter are those of the evader. This allows you to train the SOM with less parameters, which makes the problem easier.

Parameters:
relativity - Relativity choice

setGameSpeed

protected void setGameSpeed(int speed)
Define the speed to play the game on the Applet with.

Parameters:
speed - Speed of game [1-10]
